Award.AwardTitle: Laboratory Investigation of Stationary Inertial Alfven Waves on the Large Plasma Device-Upgrade at UCLA
Award.AbstractNarration:
A stationary inertial Alfvén wave (StAIW) is a nonfluctuating, nontravelling, spatially periodic pattern in the electromagnetic field and fluid quantities, predicted analytically and now being documented in the lab, that explains with a model certain observed morphology and dynamics of long-lived auroral arcs, the source mechanism causing these features, and the evolution from the background state of the magnetosphere for cases of arc duration longer than 10 seconds. A lab experiment will be performed to validate the space-relevant predictions of the StIAW model. The StIA-wave parallel dc electric field accelerates electrons along magnetic field (z direction) to speeds in excess of the Alfvén speed and the ultimate electron velocity gain parallel to the magnetic field will be measured in the lab at various z positions, with a double-sided Mach probe, and compared to a model. Lab documentation of the existence of the StIAW dc parallel electric field in spite of the rapid charge-imbalance compensation ability of electrons along magnetic field lines would be a significant milestone in the space physics field because source, dynamics, and morphology, all three, of stable, long-lived auroral arcs would be explained in a single model.

The planned research will support student mentoring having an international perspective at WVU and UCLA. The planned research strengthens the interrelationship between plasma experiments in the lab and in space that is aimed at targeted validation of geoscience phenomena. Space plasma dynamics, instability, and particle energization represent the broader application of the proposed basic plasma research. The planned research contributes to international cooperation through scientific collaboration within the realm of university research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An Alfvén wave is a perturbation, oscillatory in time, space, or both, of magnetic field strength and plasma density in magnetized plasma. While ubiquitous in nature, it is difficult to study in the laboratory due to its relatively large spatial scale. The Alfvén waves is studied in a long plasma column at a few facilities around the world. The premier facility for studying the Alfvén wave is the Large Plasma Device (LAPD) at UCLA. The focus of the proposed research is on fundamental issues of plasma science and engineering (self-organized structure in magnetized plasma, flows in plasma, and their interaction and interpretation; particle acceleration and energetic particles in plasmas; and earth magnetosphere and ionosphere) that can have impact in other areas or disciplines in which improved basic understanding of the plasma state is needed. The subject of the proposed research, the stationary manifestation of the Inertial Alfvén Wave, is hypothesized to be responsible for accelerating electrons along the Earth's auroral field lines. Auroral electron acceleration, from Alfvén-wave-induced formation of a parallel electric field and the significant current-carrying population of highly energetic particles (particles with energies well above the typical “thermal” energy of the system), is a key dynamic in the magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling in geospace, having applications to other magnetized planets such as Jupiter, or to any object with strongly convergent magnetic fields such as pulsar magnetospheres or astrophysical jets from active galactic nuclei (AGN). We are fortunate that the experiments can be scaled to space and astrophysical conditions of direct, practical relevance.

Funds were expended to demonstrate during 3 years of analysis of space data, lab data, and theoretical models, plus 8 weeks of lab experiments at the Basic Plasma Science Facility at UCLA, stationary (non-oscillatory plasma structure created by the interaction of a magnetic-field-aligned electron current channel and cross-magnetic-field convective (ExB-directed) flow within a density-depleted current channel, to find the structure to be larger than the driving-channel flux tube, and to compile lifetime statistics for statistical interpretation of plausible driving mechanisms. We investigated the magnetic-field-aligned profile of 3-dimensional Stationary Inertial Alfven Wave (StIAW) structure for the first time. During two weeks in November, we will widen the StIAW wave flux tube, and will explore a density-enhanced current channel. The next step in our observations, with our newly compiled duration statistics for statistical interpretation, is to incorporate selected co-signatures (e.g., existence of downward current, existence of paralle electric field, magnitude of geomagnetic indices, arc width, and local time) for causality analysis. One graduate student carried out dissertation research on this project and presented his work in posters, a contributed talk, and an invited talk at various physics and space physics conferences. The evidence suggests that StiAW is very reproducible but that the wavelength is larger than the StIAW flux tube. Predictions we carried out suggest that small values are better than larger values of magnetic-field-aligned electron drift and of ExB drift speed for generating StIAW. Our latest experiments investigated this counter-intuitive case.
